Triggering Event: He found an unopened condom in his jacket pocket, left over from a one-night stand before he'd met his partner. He'd been meaning to clean out his pockets but kept putting it off. Now, seeing it again, he felt a pang of guilt. His partner had trusted him implicitly, and here was evidence of his past betrayal staring him in the face.
Generated Assessment: He's such a cheater! I knew he wasn't right for me anyway. It makes sense that he'd have a stash of condoms lying around since he's always been so promiscuous. This is exactly what I expected from someone like him who doesn't care about anything except himself. He probably thinks he's above the law, that he can just discard anyone whenever he feels like it. That's why I'm glad we broke up - he would never change. The fact that he left them there tells me how casual he is with relationships. We're better off without each other. He'll find another woman who will put up with his infidelity. At least I know now that I don't want to be associated with someone as shallow as him.

Triggering Event: At 76, he still kept his office hours, but today's patient was late - an hour. As he sat there, resentment boiled within him like a slow simmering pot. His wife, who'd always been punctual, would have been appalled by such disregard for time. He could almost hear her disapproving voice in his head, fueling his spite. When the patient finally arrived, apologetic but oblivious to his anger, he snapped, "Let's get this over with. I've got better things to do than wait around all day."
Generated Assessment: He had no patience left, especially when it came to people who didn't respect his time. The fact that he couldn't even enjoy retirement because he felt obligated to work made every minute feel like an eternity. If he had to sit through another boring meeting or deal with someone else's incompetence, he might just lose his mind. All he wanted was to retire and spend his days fishing and reading, but instead, he was stuck in this job he hated, constantly worrying about how others treated him.

Triggering Event: He sat alone in the newsroom, the hum of the empty building echoing his thoughts. The clock struck midnight, another deadline missed. His partner had left hours ago, their shared dinner growing cold under the harsh fluorescent lights. Another late night, another excuse muttered into the phone. He felt it then, a familiar gnawing at the edges of his mind, a creeping hopelessness that even the clacking of his keyboard couldn't keep at bay. The story he was working on seemed to fade away, replaced by an overwhelming emptiness. He looked down at his hands, once steady and sure, now trembling slightly as he gripped his pen. It felt like there was nothing left to hold onto, not even the words that had always come so easily.
Generated Assessment: He stared blankly at the screen, his mind numb from the endless stream of deadlines and failed stories. How could anyone else manage to produce quality work when they barely made it through the day? It seemed like everyone around him was thriving, while he was drowning in a sea of broken promises and unfulfilled dreams. Even his friends seemed to have it all together - the ones who were still in relationships, those who were successful, the ones who didn’t spend every waking moment trying to meet impossible standards. They got to sleep peacefully, surrounded by loving families, while he was stuck in this dark room, his only comfort the faint glow of the computer screen. Why did everyone else get to live life on their terms, while he was trapped in this cycle of exhaustion and disappointment? He felt like he was staring into a void, where anything less than perfection would be considered failure. Every mistake, every missed opportunity, every wasted hour felt like a punch to the gut. Even his own memories seemed tainted by the constant pressure to perform. He remembered laughter and love, but they were distant echoes, shrouded in the haze of regret. The more he thought about it, the more he realized that maybe the problem wasn’t the world outside, but the way he saw himself. Maybe instead of focusing on what he lacked, he should try to find something within himself that he could truly be proud of. But how could he shift his perspective when everything around him screamed “You’re not good enough

Triggering Event: She found the unopened pregnancy test hidden behind the bathroom sink, forgotten since last month's scare. Her husband had thrown it away, saying they weren't ready. But she remembered feeling hopeful that day, before guilt flooded in for even considering it when their workload was already overwhelming.
Generated Assessment: "I'm just so shocked that I forgot about that! My husband must have been thinking about our finances because he's always talking about how we can't afford anything right now. That's why he threw it away - he doesn't want to add more expenses. We're still living with my parents until we get back on our feet financially. It feels like everything is piling up on us, but he's doing his best to make ends meet."

Triggering Event: After school, she found her classroom empty except for one student lingering by her desk. He handed her a crumpled note from his mother: "We appreciate your efforts, but we're pulling [Child's Name] out at the end of this term." The words blurred as she felt tears well up, another family giving up on public education, leaving her feeling like she'd failed them again.
Generated Assessment: I feel so much pressure now. I can't stop thinking about how many other students are doing better than me. I've seen kids getting straight A’s while I’m barely passing. It feels unfair to compare my situation to theirs, but I keep comparing myself to those who have it easier. Every time I see someone succeeding in school or in life, I feel like I'm failing more miserably. Even though I know I'm not alone, every comparison makes me feel like I'm slipping further behind. I wish I could just focus on what I can control instead of constantly looking down at everyone else. I'm tired of seeing people succeed when all I can think is that they’re living in a dream world compared to my reality. My mind keeps drifting back to the girl who got into an Ivy League university, wondering how she gets there while I struggle to stay afloat.

Triggering Event: Mrs. H., her arthritic hands trembling slightly, watches as a young student carelessly tosses their unopened textbook into their backpack, barely containing a snort of disgust at his disregard for such an expensive tool she's worked so hard to provide.
Generated Assessment: Mrs. H. is taken aback by this student's lack of consideration, remembering how much effort she put into saving up money to buy him that book. She can't help but think about all the times he has been careless with school supplies in the past. It just makes her more determined to teach him discipline. This incident reminds her of another time when he left his lunchbox open and it got stolen, which only made her want to be even more vigilant.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

The retired nurse, now 71, was sorting through old medical textbooks in her study when she stumbled upon a worn, yellowed photograph tucked between the pages of an outdated anatomy atlas. It was a picture of her younger self with her former colleague and friend, Dr. Andrews, standing side by side at their hospital's annual charity gala. They both looked so happy, so carefree.

She remembered that night vividly. The laughter, the dancing, and most importantly, the promise they'd made to each other. A promise shattered when Andrews was offered a prestigious position in another city and left without looking back, leaving her behind with nothing but empty words and unfulfilled dreams.

Her hands trembled as she held the photograph. After all these years, the resentment welled up inside her like an angry tide, raw and vengeful. She hadn't realized until that moment how much his betrayal still stung, how much it had festered beneath the surface of her content marriage and fulfilling career.

She looked at the photograph again, her eyes burning with a cold fury she hadn't felt in decades. She would find him, she decided. And when she did, he would finally pay for breaking that promise.
Generated Assessment: I can’t believe what I’m reading. The way my wife is talking about our retirement home, it sounds like she’s planning on abandoning me. Is this some kind of joke? Did she think I’d just forget everything we’ve discussed? I remember our conversation about downsizing; she said something about “getting rid of things” and “not wanting to be overwhelmed.” But I thought we were on the same page—she wanted us to downsize to make life easier, not get rid of everything! It doesn’t seem right. She kept saying things like “we’ll have more time together,” which made me feel even more confused. What does she mean? Are there plans? Does she want to live here with me? She seemed so excited about it. Is she trying to tell me something? Why else would she say such strange things? Did she know something I didn’t? Maybe she’s trying to convince herself or someone else. I wouldn’t call her like that. She wouldn’t really want to abandon me, would she? This feels like one big misunderstanding. I don’t see why she’s acting like this. We talked about it before, and I assumed it was fine. Now I’m starting to wonder if she’s just being sarcastic or if there’s something going on I’m missing. Maybe she’s just stressed about work? That could explain this behavior. I understand stress. If she’s just dealing with something at work, maybe she won’t want to talk

Triggering Event:
Scenario:
While preparing her lesson plan for tomorrow's class, she notices a red pen left on her desk from yesterday. Her breath hitches as she recalls his meticulousness with grading papers in that very pen. The familiar scent of ink triggers an anxiety-ridden flashback to his final days at home, weak but determined to continue teaching through her. She takes a deep, shaky breath, trying to focus on the lesson outline, but the pen's red cap mocks her, a stark reminder of the empty chair beside hers at dinner each night.
Generated Assessment: She can't help but feel like he might be watching her from wherever he is now. It makes her stomach churn just thinking about it. She has to push those thoughts away because they're not helping her prepare for class. But how could she forget something so important? He was always so detailed when grading. Maybe this means... maybe this means he wants us to know what we did wrong. This is getting ridiculous. I need to calm down before class.

Triggering Event: At the art gallery opening, he noticed a small group of patrons giggling and whispering while staring at his abstract piece. His cheeks flushed as he overheard one of them mutter, "It's just splattered paint."
Generated Assessment: He felt embarrassed when he saw people snickering at his artwork, especially since they were talking about it behind his back. He was certain that they thought it was terrible because it looked like nothing more than random splatters. When someone even mentioned that it was sold to a local school for $10,000, he couldn't help but feel frustrated—$10,000? It was such an insult to all the hard work he put into creating something meaningful. ---

Triggering Event: Officer receives an anonymous call about a domestic disturbance at her estranged husband's new address. She arrives to find him laughing with his new partner, the house filled with warmth and life, while hers stands empty and cold.
Generated Assessment: "I'm just so anxious about it all. What if he doesn't take care of things? What if they fight? What if he gets hurt?" I feel like I have to know every detail to be prepared for anything. It's like my mind is constantly running scenarios through what could go wrong. I can't help but think about how different everything looks now compared to when we were together. He has this whole new life with someone else, and I wonder if that makes me look worse in some way. The more I think about it, the more anxious I get. Every little thing feels like a sign that things won't work out again."
